MR. SLEIGHT to HENRY WEAKFORD. Q. Have you seen the prosecutor and his wife, and the other woman, in company in public-houses? A. Yes; they were there, whether they were in company or not.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows:—"I was pretty well out of my mind when I did it—I can prove what I said about my wife—I caught another man in the room with her with his breeches down—I begged her to get away from the house, and while I was away she went, and went to live in the same place with that man—I met her afterwards and asked her where she lived, that I might see my children, and she would not tell me—Mrs. Styles came to my mother's and tried to get me out of my lodging—I went to her on the Saturday evening and asked her what she meant, she said she would meet me at my mother's—I went there and she said, 'You accused my husband of being along with your wife'—and I said, 'I am sorry, I can almost prove it'—she then told me her husband was no use to a woman; that when he came home from the Crimea he had the bad disorder, and that accounted for how mysteriously I had received the bad disorder and my wife too, about four years and a half ago—we then went to my mother's, and Mrs. Styles began to bluster—I said I had trouble enough—she said I accused my wife wrongfully, and if it was done it was not done in her house—I said she did not know that—I that my wife was at home when Mrs. Styles was out, and I said she was there now—she said she was not—I said I would go and see, I went and knocked at the door; my wife opened the door—I shoved her aside and said I would see who was there—as I shoved her side she called out, 'Styles, look out, it is George'—as I entered the back room he turned to the fire-place and took up the poker, and my wife seised me by the throat, and he struck me with the poker on the back of my hand—I took the poker from him and hit him, I don't know whether once, or twice, or a dozen times—I lost all control of myself at that time."
COURT to ANN STYLES. Q. Was there a fire in your back parlour? A. Yes; the ironing was going on there.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

493.
JOHN GAY (34)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
Mary Ann Gay upon her neck and throat, with intent to murder her. Second Count. To do her some grievous bodily harm.

MARY ANN GAY . I am the prisoner's wife—on 5th April, I was living apart from him at Mrs. Clement's, 5, Park-lane, Clapham—I did live at 4, Mill-row, Clapham, and I went from there to Mrs. Clements—I went to try to get a lodging—no one would take me in on account of my husband—on 5th April, I saw my husband—I had been washing and I saw him against the door of the lodging—he asked me to give him a little hat brush, and I said yes, and he followed me into the passage and asked if I would have a little beer—I said, "No"—I went up stairs and got the hat brush and gave it him—I went out and left him there—I met Mrs. Clements, and I told her he was in the house—I returned with Mrs. Clements—I went in doors and sat down, and he sat down by the side of me—he went and got some beer and asked me to drink with him, and I did so—Mrs. Clements asked him to go, and I asked him myself to go—he said he had very comfortable lodgings—I said I was very glad of it, and I told him not to trouble me and I would not trouble him—he was going, and he came to the foot of the stairs and asked me to shake hands with him, and I did so—he then asked me to stop the night with him—I said,"No, you said you had a comfortable lodging, go to your lodging"—he then said he would stop—Mrs. Clements

said she hoped he would not come there, it was a quiet place and we did not want to have a noise—he again asked me to stop—I said, "No," and he left—on the following morning about 6 o'clock, I was getting my break
fast, Mrs. Clements was gone to work, and Mr. Clements was out; there were two children in the house—while getting my breakfast a knock came at the door; I went to the door and it was my husband—he asked me for a bag which he had left the night before—I said he had not left a bag there, I supposed he had left it in his room at night and had forgotten it—I looked round for the bag and I said there was no one there—he then asked me for some water—I said, "Why do you not go to your lodging"—he then said with an oath that he would cut my throat, and before the words were out of his mouth I felt the cut at my throat—I struggled with him very much and defended the cut off with my hand, and he cut the leaders of my left hand—I fell and he fell on me—he rose, and he was endeavouring to cut my throat—I fell down and was on my knees—I struggled and got the razor from him, and he put his fingers in my throat to tear the wound open—the wound bled very much indeed; it bled much more after that—my husband got up and ran away—I was very much exhausted—I hallooed murder as long as I could, and some gentleman came and said I had cut my throat as I had the razor in my hand—I said no, my husband had done it—I saw Mrs. Clements and asked her to run for a doctor, and I was taken to the hospital—I don't know of any cause for this—my husband has not been happy with me for the last three years—I believe it was jealousy, but I believe the jealousy has been on the wrong side—I have had two warrants and a summons for him for his ill usage, and the last time he said if I had him brought up again, he would give me something for it—that is about a month ago.

Cross-examined by MR. TINDAL ATKINSON Q. How long have you been married to him? A. Eleven years on the 27th of last December—I did not leave him by agreement; he left me—he left me with the furniture in the house—he left me in debt—he went to lodgings—I removed the articles away from my own house—he asked me whether I had sold the things, and I did not tell him—I said, I had the things there, but I had to pay for them—we have not been happy together for the last three years—it was at my suggestion that he left me—when he came to me this time he did not appear to be in liquor—I observed something about him that I did not like—there was a wildness about him—it was quite unusual for me to see him look so—I did not go and leave him three years ago; he left me—there was a lodger staying with me when my husband was with me; that was Mary Ann Donald—I never had any male person lodge there—I never left the prisoner with any male person; I don't recollect that I did—I did not leave him three years ago for a little while; he left me—I did not live with any man that time—I never lived with a man since I have known my husband—I know a man of the name of Metcalfe, he never stayed with me any time—I never had any improper connexion with any man since I was married.

SARAH CLEMENTS . I live in Park-lane, Clapham—my husband is a carrier, and I go out to work as a laundress—Mrs. Gay was living with me—on 5th April I saw the prisoner in the street, he Baid, "Is that Mrs. Clements?"—I said, "Yes"—he said he wanted to see Polly, meaning his wife—I went back and there was the prisoner; he sat down by the side of his wife and pressed her very much to have some beer, and I wished her to take some because I was afraid he would make a noise—he fetched a pot of porter himself and she and I partook of it—my husband did not drink any—the

I prisoner then wanted to fetch more beer, but I wished him to go—I said to I him, "Go"—he rose up to go, and then he asked his wife if she would let I him stop there that night—she said, "No" and I said, "No"—he went up the stairs and said he would stop with her—I told him she was only a I lodger and he could not—he came down again and went out at the door—I the next morning I saw Mrs. Gay bleeding from a wound in her throat—there was a great quantity of blood came from her, not so much in the kitchen, but in the passage there was a quantity of blood—I ran to the I doctor—the doctor came and dressed her throat, and she was taken to the I hospital—when I came back from the doctor the prisoner saw me in Acre-lane, and said I kept a regular b—y house and encouraged his w—e to I come there; there is not the least ground for saying I keep a house of that description—I never knew of any man living with the prisoner's wife; she I is a hard-working woman—I had seen the prisoner before—I have not heard him before make complaints of his wife.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it a delusion to say that you keep an improper house? A. Yes, it is—I don't know whether the prisoner was very wild when he was talking in that way, I did not look at him much.

WILLIAM YOUNG . I live in Park-place, No. 5 is at the back of me—about three minutes before 6 o'clock that morning, I was in my garden and heard screams—I went to No. 5 and saw Mrs. Gay, she was at the end of the passage on the edge of the kerb throwing her hands about and seemingly in great pain—she had at that time a razor in her hand—I took the razor from her and gave it to the policeman—the razor was bloody—I saw the prisoner about five minutes afterwards, I saw him wash his hands in a pond—I walked by his side till I met a policeman, and he gave himself up—after I gave up the razor at the station he gave up the sheath and said it belonged to it.

THOMAS NEWMAN (Police-sergeant, V 25). About ten minutes after 6 o'clock that morning, I was on duty at Clapham—I saw the prisoner followed by the last witness and several others; they said, "Stop that man, he has cut his wife's throat"—the prisoner said, "I don't want to be stopped, I have done it, I was coming to the station to give myself up"—after I took him to the station, I went to the house and saw Mrs. Gay on the floor, the doctor was attending her—the place was bloody all over; the passage, the floor, and the walls—this is the razor I received from the last witness—the prisoner took this sheath of it out of his own pocket at the station—I think he said, "This is the sheath."

SARAH WILLIAMS . I am bar-maid at the Oxford-arms, Clapham—about 5 o'clock on the morning of the 6th April the prisoner came there—he had some brandy and ale—he remained till about a quarter before 6 o'clock; he then left and was away about ten minutes, he came back and asked for more brandy—he said, "I am going to pay you for it, this is the last I shall ever drink; I have out my wife's throat, I have come here to wait for the policeman to take me"—I begged him not to stop—his hands were covered with blood—he said, "Look here"—he just went in the parlour and then went away.

ELIZA DRUMMOND . I live at 39, Park-place, opposite to where Mrs. Gay lived—on 6th April, about 6 o'clock, I heard several screams—I looked out of window and saw the prisoner and his wife struggling in the passage—his wife was upon her knees, and the prisoner seemed as if he was getting up from his wife—he was at her back—he rushed into the road and then ran up the street.

JAMES BUNKART . I am house surgeon at Guy's Hospital—on the morn
ing

of 6th April, Mary Ann Gay was brought in—I did not see her till about 11 o'clock—she had two incised wounds on her throat, one about four inches long, extending from the left ear to the middle of the throat—the other was about two inches long, about an inch and a half below it, towards the centre of the throat; I should think about half an inch deep—they were cut from left to right—the principal depth was on the left side of the throat—she was not in danger—I found some small wounds on her hands.

Crost-examined. Q. They were not of depth enough to injure life? A. No, they were not—the principal wound was on the side of the neck—the cuts on the hands were such as would be made by attempting to defend the throat.
JURY. Q. Did either of the wounds present the appearance of having been torn? A. I could not judge that.
COURT. Q. Were the ends of the wounds torn? A. No.

GUILTY .—
DEATH recorded.

494.
WILLIAM DUNN (20), and
SARAH DUNN (40)
, Robbery on
Jane Bellamy, and stealing from her person a shawl, and 15s. in money, the property of
John Bellamy.

JANE BELLAMY . I am the wife of John Bellamy, of 115, Union-street, Borough—about a quarter to 12 o'clock on the evening of 21st April I was with a Mrs. Mauler at the Red Lion public-house, very nearly opposite to where I live—I had not been in there more than while I got served with my supper beer, which I had gone for—I gave the barman a sovereign—the prisoners were there when I went in—there were a great many people there—I had known the prisoners before, by living in the neighbourhood—I received 19s. 6d. change from the barman—the prisoners saw me receive it—having received it I left the Red Lion with Mrs. Mauler—the prisoners followed us out instantly—I was crossing the road to go to my house, with my beer in my hand—the male prisoner came up to me, and asked me what I meant by calling his father moucher—I had not called his father moucher—he said if I had made use of such an expression my husband was to come out and show what he could do—my husband came up out of his shop—he is a boot and shoe maker—we have been residing in that house three years—when he came up the male prisoner instantly attacked him, struck him, and they both fell—the prisoner got up off the ground, turned round, and struck me—I was about two yards from where the scuffle took place between him and my husband—I tried to help my husband off the ground—I did not strike the prisoner in doing that—I had not struck him at all before he came and struck me in the face—I had a black eye, and my forehead was all scratched—I fell on the ground—at this time I had the change of the money in my right hand—having struck me, he made a grasp at my hand, and all the money was taken from me but 4s. 6d.—he held my hand, wrenched it open, and took the money out, but some of the silver fell on the ground—he picked some of it up, ran away, and I pursued him—the female prisoner did not do anything to me, before she stole my shawl—nobody else did anything to me whilst I was on the ground—I ran after the male prisoner, and came up to him at Princes-street, which is in Union-street—he then struck me again a violent blow in the face—I fell, and he ran away—I got up and pursued him—I called out "Thief," and "Police"—when I was down the second time the female prisoner came up, and assisted

in pulling me about till she pulled the shawl off my back—she is his mother—she then ran away to the end of the buildings where they live—I could see her—she threw the shawl to another son, who is not in custody—he was standing at the end of the buildings where they live—I cannot say whether that son is older or younger than the one at the bar—the son went with the shawl up the buildings, where they live—I had got up from the ground at this time—some man, I don't know who, was holding the male prisoner during this time, about thirty or forty yards, I should think, from where I had been knocked down the second time—he had run away after I was knocked down the second time—I saw him given into the custody of Ireland, the policeman—I never got back any of the money that was taken out of my hand.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Was this a quarter to 12 on Saturday night? A. Yes—I am sure I had only gone into the Red Lion a few minutes—I had been in before in the evening for a pint and a half of porter, as I always do about 9 o'clock—I had not been in more than once before—I had known the prisoners by sight about four years—I never drank with them—I was never in their company, except going in and out there for my beer—my husband did not go with me to the Red Lion—I do not recollect taking off my bonnet and shawl, and offering a little fight, after the young man came up and asked me about mouchur—a person took my shawl off, and the remains of my bonnet, which was torn—that was close to my own door—they were off—as soon as this altercation took plape a large number of people collected round there; there always is—I saw the male prisoner, but none of the others, picking up some of the money that went on the ground—I did not try to help the male prisoner on to the ground—I am quite sure I did not touch him—I am positive I did not raise my hand at all—the prisoner and my husband fell on the ground together—I did not then raise my foot, or anything of the sort—I swear that I took no part in the struggle at all—I was exactly opposite the Red Lion when I lost my shawl.

COURT. Q. When the prisoner was taking the money out of your hand, where was your other hand? A. It might have been as it is now—I was down on the ground when he took it out of my hand—he wrenched my hand open—I did not use my other hand at all—I was holding his brother, who is not in custody—I did not grasp at any person—my husband was persuaded to go back and take care of the shop, for fear we should have been robbed—our shop is all exposed—there is no window—he went and left me in the prisoner's hands—I resisted when the female prisoner came up to take my shawl—she was using most abusive language—there was a great crowd—nobody helped to stop this—I am quite sure that I had been into no other public-house that evening but the Red Lion—I took a part, and my husband took a part of the pint and a half of porter that I got in the early part of the evening—neither I nor my husband have ever had any words with the female prisoner during the four yeare we have known them—I had two shawls on—a person living opposite took the large shawl and my bonnet, and minded them till I sent for them on Sunday morning—I don't know whether that woman is here—I was perfectly sober.

ANN MAULER . I am the wife of Joseph Mauler, of 20, Pepper-street, Union-street, Borough, a bellhanger and gasfitter—he is employed by his father—on Saturday night, 21st April, I was with the last witness in the Red Lion; only while she was being served with a pot of half-and-half—I saw the sovereign changed, and the change handed to her—the prisoners were both in the public-house at the time—I knew them by sight—they

were never acquaintances of mine—Mrs. Bellamy and I left the public-house—when we got into the road the male prisoner came up and said to Mrs. Bellamy, "Why did you call my father moucher?" she said, "No; I was not talking about you at all; I was talking to my friend"—I don't know the meaning of moucher—Mrs. Bellamy had not used the word in my presence—the prisoner said, "Because, if you were, I would take it out of your b—y husband"—with that he struck Mrs. Bellamy—the prisoner's mother was with him then—Mr. Bellamy came across, and asked what wag the matter—I did not see him before the male prisoner had struck Mrs. Bellamy—it was a violent blow in the face, with his fist—it stunned her, and knocked her down—she fell on the ground, and then the male prisoner wrenched hold of her hand, and took some of the silver out, and part of it dropped on the ground—he stooped to piok it up—I laid hold of his hand, and said, "Don't rob the woman of her money, give it to her"—he said, "What money? I have got none"—I am positive I saw him take the money, and pick it up from the ground—no one interfered with Mrs. Bellamy while she was on the ground—she got up and ran after the male prisoner, whose brothers I know by sight—two of them were there while Mm Bellamy was on the ground—I think they are older than he—they interfered, and tried to get him away from Mrs. Bellamy while she was on the ground—she had not got hold of him—they only said, "Come away," they did not do anything—while Mrs. Bellamy was on the ground the first time the female prisoner struck her on the face—I can't say whether Mrs. Bellamy saw her do so—there was a crowd of people—it is a very bad neighbourhoodz—the male prisoner ran on, and then turned round and struck Mrs. Bellamy, who was pursuing him—she got up to him near Princes-street, which is five or six yards from the place where she was first knocked down—he struck her and knocked her down a second time—while she was on the ground, I saw the female prisoner tear her shawl off and give it to one of her sons who had been present at the first transaction—it was a silk shawl, with large flowers on—the female prisoner then ran up the court—the prisoners do not live very far from where Mrs. Bellamy was knocked down the second time—I saw the male prisoner stopped by a gentleman—after he knocked Mrs. Bellamy down the second time, he continued his flight till the gentleman stopped him—he had got about four or five yards from where he knocked her down the second time—Mrs. Bellamy cried out, "Stop thief!" and I saw him stopped and given in charge to a policeman.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you lived in the neighbourhood? A. I was brought up in it—I have known the prisoners and their family, by sight, eleven years—I can't say whether, during that time, they have been living in the same neighbourhood—I have seen them about—I did not know where they lived—I did not, nor do I now know the buildings down where they lived—Mrs. Bellamy asked me to go across with her to get her supper beer—I live about two or three minutes' walk from the Red Lion—Mrs. Bellamy asked me to go, because she and I were next door neighbours—I had come direct from ray home, and was going out to market to buy what I wanted—I had not been to the Red Lion or to any other public-house before, that evening—I am positive that I took nothing at all when I was in the Red Lion—I only know the prisoners by sight—I have never been in their company or drank with them.

COURT. Q. You say Mrs. Bellamy asked you to go across with her to get her supper beer? A. Yes—she had not been drinking—she was per
fectly sober—there were not the least symptoms of disagreement in the

public-house—the Bellamy's keep a shop, and I suppose Mr. Bellamy went back to his shop because he could not leave it—I do not know whether he left his wife to fight it out—I did not see what he did—I saw some scuffling between him and the prisoner—he was knocked down two or three times, and after that, I think, he went back to his shop; oh, I forgot, a boy came up and said to him that there was a customer in the shop—this shindy might have taken twenty-five minutes.

JAMES VERNON . I am a traveller, and live at 84, Westminster-road—I was in Union-street, Borough, on Saturday evening, 21st April, about five minutes to 12—I did not know any of the parties in this case—I saw the prosecutrix and Mrs. Mauler—they stepped on to the foot path and were passing immediately before me—I did not see the house they came from—they stepped on to the foot path as if they came across the road—I saw the male prisoner come up immediately—he assaulted the prosecutrix, and pulled off his coat, and said he would fight her husband or any other person she liked to bring, and immediately upon that he made a rush at her, struck her, and knocked her down, and I saw him make a grasp at one of her hands—it was in the face, I think, that he struck her—he laid hold of her hand—they both fell down, and money fell from the proseoutrix's hand—I did not see what became of it; it scattered on the ground—there were two others, I believe, with the prisoner; they were all together, and there was a scramble for the money—both the prisoners, and two or three others took part in the scramble—I cannot say whether the male prisoner suc
ceeded in getting any of the money—I saw Mrs. Bellamy on the ground—I did not notice anything done to her by anybody while on the ground—she and the male prisoner got up almost together—the prisoner attempted to run away—he ran for perhaps four or five yards—Mrs. Bellamy pursued him and he immediately turned round, struck her in the face, and knocked her down—he then ran away—a crowd immediately collected; I did not go into the crowd, but I saw a policeman coming up, who went to them—when I first saw Mrs. Bellamy she had on a dark shawl which she took off, but under that she had a light shawl, apparently a silk one—I saw her after she had been knocked down the second time—she had no shawl at all on then—I should say three or four minutes elapsed between my losing sight of her, and seeing her the second time.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see her also take her bonnet off? A. Yes—I did not see her husband at all, till after the male prisoner was given in custody and it was all over—there was not a considerable crowd immediately—I do not know the Bed Lion.

COURT. Q. You stood on the pavement and looked on? A. Yes—I should not think it lasted above five minutes—I do not know whether Mrs. Bel
lamy's bonnet and shawl were loose, and she gave them to some one for safety; but she pursued the prisoner—she was knocked down the first time, and she immediately threw them off—I could form no opinion as to whether there had been any drinking—Mrs. Bellamy appeared sober—I did not see her husband knocked down at all—the male prisoner made a rush at Mrs. Bellamy's hand before she fell down.

JOHN CLEMENTS IRELAND (Policeman, M 217). I was on duty on this Saturday night in the neighbourhood of Union-street, Borough—I saw a row in the street, and a crowd of people—Mr. Vernon said something to me—I went up to the prisoner and he was given in my custody by two men.
DENIS SCANNELL (Policeman, M 177). On Sunday morning, about half-past 12, at her own house, which is in a court leading out of Union-street,

the female prisoner was given in my custody for stealing a shawl, and being concerned with her son in robbing Mrs. Bellamy of her shawl—when I told her the charge she said she was an honest woman and knew nothing about the shawl; that if I went up stairs I should find the shawl there—I went up stairs with Mr. Bellamy—while going up stairs I heard a rush at the street door—I found no shawl up there—there was another constable in the passage—the place was very dark.

GUILTY —
Confined Eight Days each.

495.
WILLIAM HARPER (26)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Thomas Faye.

GEORGE STOWER . I am a cab-driver of 4, Parliament-street, St. George's Market, Southwark—I knew the deceased Thomas Faye, a coal-porter, he was about forty years of age—on Friday, 16th March, I saw him at the Elephant and Castle public-house, near Vauxhall Railway-station, about half-past 9 or twenty minutes to 10 o'clock—the prisoner was also there—they both appeared as if they had been drinking, they were rather the worse for liquor—I heard them quarrelling, but did not know what it was about—one of them proposed to go out and fight; I cannot say which, but they were both willing, and I tried to prevent them—I held the deceased and pre
vented him from going out: after a little struggle I said, "Well; if you will go, you must go and take your chance"—they both left and went under the arches, somewhere: into the grounds of the station. I remained some few minutes, and then went towards the arches, where my cab was standing for hire when the trains came in—I heard a noise like a fall, and went and saw Thomas Faye fall, just as I got to the spot—he laid on his back very quiet—I did not lift him up—he did not speak or make any movement—the prisoner was about three yards in front of his feet—he was lifted up—I did not see him taken away—I went to the Elephant and Castle, remained there perhaps two minutes, and then went away to my cab.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. Had both the men had a good deal of drink? A. Yes; but they could walk—Faye was a very stout healthy man—I have heard that he was in the habit of sleeping in the gas factory—he was very dirty in his habits—I have never seen the waiters at the tap-room carry water for him to wash himself—he was often at the public-house.

DENNIS HARRINGTON . I am a labourer of James'-place, Fore-street, Lambeth—I was at the Elephant and Castle on Friday, 16th March, and heard the prisoner and deceased quarrelling about work—I could not under
stand exactly what was said, but after some time they agreed to go out and fight—I do not know which proposed it, one was as willing as the other—they were both under the influence of liquor—they left the Elephant and Castle together to fight—I remained behind some little time—I then went to see what was taking place—(The witness was cautioned that he need not say any
thing tending to criminate himself,)—I do not want to say anything—I will speak the truth—I took no part whatever in encouraging them to fight—I saw them sparring together, and after that I saw the prisoner lay hold of Faye by the legs and chuck him on his head—he fell on the back of his head, as far as I could see—I said to the prisoner that it was a shame, and he struck me—I struck him back again—I did not see Faye afterwards till I saw him on Monday night—he was helped up and led away—I cannot say whether he walked—he seemed sensible—he was not bleeding that
I saw—I did not see the back of his head, or whether he had any wound—I saw the prisoner on the Tuesday following, and he told me he was very sorry for what had happened.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the deceased? A. Yes: I do not believe he had any place of abode—he lived in a gas factory, and I believe he used to sleep there—I do not believe he has slept in a bed for a couple of years—I do not know that he slept among the ashes—he was a very dirty man, and was constantly drinking. I have seen him wash himself in the public room.

JOHN JAMES PARSONS . I am a labourer of Kingswood-place, South Lam
beth—on Friday, 16th March, about half-past 9 o'clock, I was returning from work, and saw the prisoner and the deceased come out of the Elephant and Castle—they crossed over the road and went into one of the railway arches—there were one or two others with them—I stood at the gate of the Vaux
hall station and looked in—it was within the enclosure—I stood there two or three minutes, and saw them pull off their smock frocks for the purpose of fighting—they stood sparring for a minute or two, and then the prisoner rushed at Faye with his head downwards, caught hold of his legs, and turned him over—he fell on the back of his head very heavily—he was the heavier man of the two, and about forty years of age—he laid there for a few seconds, groaning, and was picked up—he stood up as well as he could, and then Harper went at him a second time—there was more sparring, and he went in to him and turned him over in the same way, and the fall was much heavier than the first—he fell on the back of his head—they were both intoxicated—I remained two or three minutes, but he was not sensible—he never spoke; he groaned very much, and was dragged away to the Elephant and Castle—I then went for a policeman, but could not find one, and when I came back I saw the prisoner and Harrington fighting.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen either of them before? A. I had seen the deceased—I cannot say that I have seen the prisoner, but am quite sure he is the man—they passed me on the opposite side going to the arches, but I could not hear what they said to each other—the deceased was much heavier and taller, and apparently a much more powerful man than the prisoner—they were both intoxicated.
MR. SHARPE. Q. How long was all this taking place under the arches? A. I should think twenty minutes—I did not see the back of the deceased's head and cannot say whether there was any wound.

JOHN FORRESTER . I am a horse dealer, of 1, Freeport-place, Wandsworth-road; on Friday, 16th March, I was at the Elephant and Castle when the deceased was brought there; he was like half tipsy; stupid—I looked at his head and saw just a little cut at the back of it, about as large as my nail, and clotted with blood—I can't exactly say the size, on account of the hair—after I had washed it he came to a little bit, and I tried to persuade him to go to the hospital, but he would not—there was a small quantity of blood, enough for me to see—it was such a blow as might be occasioned by his falling with the back of his head on a stone or hard substance—I stopped with him till 11 or 12, I left him then; I saw him again on Saturday morning; he told me that he had been into the gas works again to sleep—he seemed very bad and complained of his head—I was with him about an hour, and tried to persuade him again to go to the hospital in a cab, but he would not, and I did not see him again till Monday, the 19th, at 10 or 11 o'clock—I then got a cab and took him to the workhouse; he appeared very bad—he seemed fixed and stupid—I kept going every day in and out
to see him, till within a quarter of an hour of his death—I saw his body at the Coroner's Inquest.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know that he was in the habit of sleeping at the gas house? A. Yes; I do not know that he slept among the cinders—he was three-parts of his time at the Elephant and Castle—he might have been employed one day out of two or three—he was a great drinker.

MICHAEL LEWIS . I am an inmate and wardsman of Lambeth Poorhouse—on Monday, the 19th, about 5 o'clock, the deceased was brought there—he appeared rather lightheaded, and complained of his head—he was left in my charge—he could walk and stand, but he went to bed half an hour after he came, and complained of a violent pain in his head—I looked at the back of his head; there was a cut or wound about an inch long, with a piece of sticking plaister on it—I took the old plaister off and put new on about an hour after he was brought in—the medical officer was sent for, who ordered him to go to bed and have all nourishment, wine, bread and butter and tea, and whatever he could take, which I gave him; but he could not take much—he was put into a bath and cleaned, he came to me—he complained next morning of a violent pain across his head, in front, and seemed much worse—he had taken the medicine that I gave him—he had constant fits till Saturday the 4th, when he died about a quarter past 4 in the afternoon—the first fit he had was on Wednesday night—he was a little sensible when he came out of the fits, but he had no time before the next fit took him.

HENRY ST. JOHN BUTLER . I am house surgeon and medical officer of Lambeth Workhouse—on Monday, 19th March, I was sent for to attend upon Thomas Faye, about 5 o'clock in the afternoon—I found him in the bath room washing himself—I accosted him—his replies were confused and incoherent—I asked him what was the matter with him; he said, "Nothing"—my attention was directed by the bath man to his head—I examined it, and found a slight wound about three-quarters of an inch long; it appeared to be incised, and such as might have been inflicted with a flint or a sharp stone, or any sharp instrument—I removed the plaister, and found it was in process of healing—in my opinion a violent fall on the back of the head on a stone would probably produce it.

COURT. Q. Could you tell whether the wound had bled much? A. I should presume not; there was a little clotted blood on the hair—it was a sort of wound more likely to be caused by a fell than a blow; the small quantity of blood would lead me to that conclusion.

MR. SHARPE. Q. Was he a heavy person? A. A remarkably heavy man, a very fine man—his being heavy would be more likely to cause a wound of this kind—after I had examined him in the bath room he was received into a ward by my orders—I saw him again in about an hour; he was then leaning his head in his hand—I spoke to him, and he complained of his head—I ordered his head to be shaved in order that I might make a more complete examination—that was done—I ordered him a mustard plaister—I did not at that time detect any injury to the brain, though I sus
pected it—the wound had only penetrated the scalp—the pupils of his eyes were somewhat dilated; that, and other symptoms, led me to the conclusion that he was suffering from concussion of the brain—he said he had lost his appetite, and complained of great oppression in breathing—I had him put to bed, and saw him twice next day—I had received no information as to the particulars of this fight, but from the information I received, and from the symptoms, I judged he was suffering from compression of the brain, and treated him for that.

COURT. Q. If he had been injured and tripped up twice bo that he fell on the back of his head, would that have accounted for what you saw? A. It might—I don't think the fact of his having been of intemperate habits would make any difference in this injury—by concussion I simply mean stunning, from which a person recovers shortly; compression is the result of the slow oozing of blood on the surface of the brain, which gradually causes that effect—a patient is less likely to recover from that than from concus
sion—it is a small oozing from the brain or one of its vessels.

MR. SHARPE. Q. I believe on the Tuesday evening he was half delirious? A. Yes; those symptoms kept on increasing—he had an epileptic fit on Wednesday evening; those continued to the time of his death—I was not with him at the exact moment of his death, but I was shortly before—I afterwards made a post-mortem examination—I first opened the head—I found a quantity of extravasated blood on the surface of the brain, and towards the base—I collected it; there was about three ounces of fluid blood—I cannot exactly define how much there was at the base of the brain; the blood there was lying on the right side, at the back of the head, on a level with the ear—it commenced exactly at the cut which was just at the apex, and went to the back part; it had gravitated down to the base of the brain—the blood had all proceeded from an artery which was wounded; that would be likely in time to cause death—I saw the extent to which it had gravitated, and it must have destroyed life—it would be likely to cause epileptic fits with other symptoms—the ruptured artery on the brain was the immediate cause of death—I examined the skull, it was unusually thin—if he had been tripped up by his legs and fallen, it might have caused both the extravasated blood and the wound; it is a common cause—I attach no importance to the scalp wound, it was purely external; both the external and the internal rupture of the artery were, at the same part—the proba
bility of such a rupture would be increased by reason of the heavy weight of the man, and would be still further increased by the remarkable thinness of the skull; the thinner the skull is the more the external violence would be felt—I examined the brain, and found it in an unusually healthy condition; there was nothing in it to cause death, except the rupture of the vessel and the blood in the brain—I found a fracture of the skull extending from the apex, or about an inch below it, to about an inch from the cut, extending through the temporal bone right through the bones of the ear in a diagonal direction; it was a linear fracture without depression—I should attribute such a fracture more to a fall than a blow.

COURT. Q. You say there was a crack, but no depression of the bone on the brain? A. Yes—a sudden knock would cause it, which would be increased by the man being heavy and his skull not being thick—I attri
bute death to the effusion of blood—we have many cases where persons recover from simple fracture of the skull; if it had only been a linear fracture the patient might have recovered—seeing the blood that oozed from the rupture, I am of opinion that that was the cause of death.

Cross-examined. Q. When the case first came before you, did you think it was a serious case? A. Yes—I did not feel certain what had been the nature of the injury he had received, or whether he had received any—that there was some effusion of the brain I felt certain, but had no history before me—I did not consider the little cut at the back of the head of any conse
quence by itself—I felt certain that a fall had caused it—I was not aware, during life, that there had been any fracture of the skull—I think it more likely to have arisen from a blow or a series of blows—the body was gene
rally

healthy—the cause of death was solely and entirely to be found in the brain—I should say that a man must fall at least four feet to cause that rupture of an artery of the brain—a man drunk and falling down might do it.
COURT. Q. Supposing a man were standing, and his legs were tripped up, would he fall four feet? A. Yes, this man would, for he was six feet high—his head would fall four or five feet, I should say.

MR. DUKE to FORRESTER. Q. Did the deceased at any time challenge you to fight? A. When he was tipsy he challenged any one—he was very quarrelsome when he was tipsy, but when he was sober he was a very quiet man.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

495.
CHARLES VOWLES (25)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
James Luscombe with intent to murder him. Second count. With intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.
MESSRS. METCALFE and BEASELEY conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES LUSCOMEE (Policeman, P.) On Wednesday night, 11th April, I was on duty in Pomeroy-street—the prisoner was given into my custody by a female who said in his presence that he had assaulted her—there were three marks of violence on her face—I told him he must go to the station with me—he said, "What! for two such b—y stinking wh—s as them; as for you, I will lay you dead in the road if you attempt to put a hand upon me"—I persuaded him to go to the station quietly, which he refused to do—I took hold of him by the arm—he was trying to get his arm away from me, and struck me a blow on the face—I took him by the cuff of his coat, and put my other hand inside his cravat and said, "Now then, for what you were going to do"—I took him to the station and he was dis
charged, the woman was obliged to take out a summons—I saw him again about five minutes after he left the station, near the Montpelier public-house, Queen's-road, Peckham—I was passing and he said, "Oh, you b—smot; you have not got your wish to-night"—I told him it was not my wish to lock him up, and I had not said anything about it at the station; that I did not tell them he had assaulted me—he said, "No, you did not; will you come and have some beer?"—I said, "No, thank you"—I walked away—I saw him again about 12 o'clock at night, outside the Victoria beer-shop, in Pomeroy-street—I was still on my beat—he was halloing and making a great noise—I went down—several of his mates were there, and when he saw me he said, "This is the b—that took me to the station to-night, I should like to give him a doing"—I persuaded him to go home, and think no more of it; two of his mates got hold of him—he said, "Let me go, I will give that b—a doing to-night"—that was all he said that night—I saw him again the following night about 12 o'clock, in front of the Victoria public-house—Cox, a constable, was with me—I heard several people talking—the prisoner came out, I did not know he was there—he began halloing and said "I wonder where this b—snot is who took me to the station last night, if I could see him I would soon do for him"—one of his mates pointed across the road and said, "There stand two"—the prisoner then ran across the road and said, "This is the b—that took me to the station last night," pointing to me—he came up quickly and said, "You are the one that took me to the station last night, are you not?"—I said, "Yes; have not you forgotten that yet?"—I persuaded him to think nothing more home—I said, "That is all settled as far as you and I are

concerned"—he said, "Yes, you b—, I will settle you yet"—I persuaded him to go home—he went a short distance up the street—I stopped there—he came back in about five minutes with one of his mates, and walked round me—his mate said, "Never mind, Charlie, we' are in our own street; we can do as we like here, and as for those b—snots, it would take forty of them to take us to the station"—I said nothing—the prisoner came up to me and kept threatening me—I persuaded him to go away home—he shoved up against me at one time, and then went away up the street towards his own home—I did not follow him for nearly five minutes, and then that was the direction I was going in—I saw him standing at his own door, and passed him—he followed me almost directly—I was one or two paces in front of him—he kept on threatening me—I persuaded him to go in—he said, "Certainly, will you allow me to smoke my cigar?" putting it in his mouth—I said, "Certainly"—he said, "How can I smoke it without a light?"—I said, "You can get a light inside"—he said, "I think I have got a match here," putting his hand in his right pocket; and instead of taking out a match, he took out a knife, looked over his right shoulder as if he was going to strike a match, opened the knife, and I heard the spring of it—he threw his arm out to it's full length and aimed at my cheek or throat—I turned my head round over my shoulder, put it down, and received the stab just behind the left shoulder—he then rushed at me, and struck me with the knife in his hand—I had got my staff out and I struck at him and guarded the knife off—he rushed at me a third time in the same way, and I struck his hand and guarded the knife off—the fourth time I struck his hand and knocked the knife out of it, upon that he turned away from me as if he was going to run down the street—I saw my mate come up the street, and I called out, "Mind the knife, he has stabbed me"—he was run
ning as fast as he could—I saw him strike my mate and knock him down in the road—I followed—he ran down the street until he got to the passage from Pomeroy-street, and just as he was going through, I made a grasp at him, missed my aim, and fell over the posts—I got up, followed him, and caught him in Cameron-street—Cox was there—I sprang my rattle for assistance, and he was taken to the station—my shoulder had a very severe stab, and bled very much—I have not the use of it yet—I have been under medical care for some time—this knife (produced) was picked up—it is the one the prisoner had in his hand—I told the constable Holdaway where
abouts it was that I had been struck.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. At the time you saw him on the night of the 11th was not he partially in liquor when the two women came up? A. Certainly he had been drinking—one of his mates was in his company—I do not know whether his name is Barraclough—I cannot say whether he followed to the station—I saw him outside the door when we came out—the prisoner was discharged at the station at a quarter to eleven—it was about twelve when I saw him in Pomeroy-street—I did not see him come out of the Victoria—I saw him outside, and I had not seen him go in—this was Tuesday in Easter week—I know England's manu
factory—I have heard since that the prisoner worked there—I do not know that the men were off work at that time on account of the holidays—there were several other men, who I call his mates, outside the Victoria—he crossed the road to me—I am quite sure a woman spoke to me while I was there, I did not know her, I have not seen her since—she did not advise me not to interfere with the man, and not to take any notice of him, for he was very drunk—no woman spoke to me to that effect—there is not the

least forgetfulness on my part—the prisoner was not led away by any of his mates, not on the 12th, the second night—he was not so much in liquor that he required assistance in going home—he had been drinking, but he knew well what he was about—he made four attacks on me and ran away—I had not taken him into custody that night before this—I was attacked in Pomeroy-street, about 150 yards from the Victoria, near the place where the prisoner lodges with a person named Gray—I knocked the knife out of his hand and ran after him, saying, "Mind the knife, he has stabbed me"—I ran 300 or 400 yards after him before I caught him—I fell with violence on the same shoulder on which I had received the injury—I ultimately took him into custody myself—I had never seen him before the night of the 11th—there was a man named Crutcher there—I cannot; say whether he had been drinking at the Victoria—he seemed to have been drinking, but he knew very well what he was about—the expression I referred to, about forty policemen taking him to the station, was used by the other man.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Was your shoulder cut before you fell? A. Yes; there were not any stones where I fell; but whether there were or not my shoulder was cut by the knife—the woman spoke to me after the prisoner had gone away the first time; I can't say whether she came to caution me—she did not say, "For God's sake, policeman, go away; whatever you do, don't interfere with them"—the prisoner came back to me while the woman was speaking to me.

CHARLES COX (Policeman, P 346.) On 12th April, about twelve o'clock, I was in Clifton-fields—I met Luscombe in Pomeroy-street—I remember the people turning out from the Victoria public-house, and among others the prisoner—we were then standing on the other side of the street—the prisoner crossed over, pointed to Luscombe, and said, "That is the b—that took me to the station; it would take forty b—policemen to take me there to-night; if ever you put a hand upon me again it will be worse for you," or "I will do for you"—Luscombe told him that he had nothing to say to him, and said, u Why don't you go away home?"—a man then came out of the public-house with some beer; he asked for a drink—he said, "Why don't you drink and go home?"—the prisoner said, u The police
man did more than his duty last night;" and he said that he would keep in the street all night if he liked—I then went on my beat, and left Lus
combe to go on his—a few minutes afterwards Crutcher called me—I went up the street, and found the prisoner in Luscombe's custody—Luscombe was staggering back, and said to me, "Look out for the knife"—I made a catch at the prisoner to catch hold of him very quickly, and I received a blow from him on the side of my head with something very hard; I believe it was not his fist—I did not see anything in his hand, but I think there must have been something beyond that which nature gave him—a stone in a handkerchief would produce such an effect as I felt; I was knocked down Benseless—two or three minutes after I came to myself I found that Lus-combe had taken the prisoner—I followed them to the station, and found Luscombe bleeding from the back—I saw the prisoner at the station, and found on him this stone (produced)—it was done up in this handkerchief in the way it is now; there was a knot tied above the stone to keep it there—the prisoner was charged with stabbing Luscombe—he said, "You have not found the knife"—that was all he said—he had been drinking, but was not drunk; he knew what he was about.
Cross-examined. Q. How far is it from Pomeroy-street to the station; about a mile? A. No, not half a mile: it is about that—I have been

stationed there about eighteen months—I saw by the prisoner's manner that he had been drinking—I had not seen him that or the preceding day—I have known him by sight; I believe he works at England's factory—I searched him and found this stone in his pocket—I found Lusoombe stag
gering when I ran up—I did not see any one in the street but Luscombe and the prisoner—I saw no one after I left the public-house—I did not see Luscombe have anything outside the pnblio-house—I believe a pint of beer was brought out; I did not see Crutcher and Luscombe partake of it—I saw the prisoner take hold of it, but do not know whether he drank; I walked away; I took none of it—I do not know what Luscombe took—I lost my senses—I am quite sure of that—Crutcher took me up—I believe they ran into Kendall-street—I did not follow them.

JOHN HOLDAWAY (Policeman, P 219). On Thursday night; in conse
quence of what Luscombe told me, I went into Pomeroy-street, and found this knife lying in the carriage-road, about two yards from the footway, near the spot where Luscombe described that he had been assaulted—it was open as it is now, and slightly wet with a little rain that had fallen—I took it to the station and gave it to the sergeant.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the Victoria? A. Yes, it is about half way between the Victoria and the Queen's-road, about two hundred yards from the Victoria—I found it about 4 in the morning—I am sure that was about the time—while I was searching only one of the constables spoke to me, the one who was on the beat in Luscombe's place—no civilian spoke to me—I looked about the entrance to Kendall-street and Powis-place, which leads from Pomeroy-street to Kendall-street.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you find it near the place pointed out to you by Luscombe? A. Luscombe described that place.

ELIZABETH MATILDA COOMBES . I live at 45, Bedford-cottages, Peckham—on 11th April, in consequence of something which had been done to me, I gave the prisoner into custody, and went to the station—I had sent for a policeman—as I followed to the station, I heard the prisoner say to Luscombe, "I will do for you, I will watch you"—he used bad language, but I could not say what words—I never saw him to my knowledge before that night.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you drank with him on that night? A. By his pushing me into the place—he went quietly to the station after the police
man had hold of him—he was discharged there.

JOSIAH CRUTCHER . I am a dairyman in Pomeroy-street—on the night of 12th April, about a quarter to 12, I was at the Victoria public-house, and saw the prisoner—he was not drunk, but he had been drinking—he went out before me and was talking to the two constables—he was threatening Luscombe that he would do for him, for some grievance that had happened the night before—he said, "This is the b that took me last night, he shall never take me any more"—I got a pot of beer for my supper in a can and asked the prisoner to drink, saying, "Do not say any more, go home"—he drank, I believe, and Luscombe said, "I do not want to have anything to say to you, as far as last night, that is forgotten, and if you do not say anything to me I shall say nothing to you"—he walked on and I stopped behind—Luscombe followed him—I then followed and saw them some dis
tance off struggling together—I stepped back and spoke to Cox—I after
wards saw Cox knocked down—I assisted him up and stopped with him—the prisoner ran away; Cox was insensible for five minutes.
Cross-examined. Q. How long had you been at the Victoria? A. About ten minutes—I had not been there before—I had left Deptford at 11 o'clock

—I do not say I had not had a glass of beer anywhere—I came home with an old gentleman; there were three of us, we had a pint or a pot, I don't know which—I was as sober as I am at this moment; I had half a glass of gin at the Victoria—if I had had two or three pints of beer it would not have made much difference to me—I heard the prisoner say, "No forty policemen shall take me to the station"—he was a little fresh—I did not know him till the day before, as I stood at my gate he walked up with two or three friends.

JOHN SWAN FLOWER . I am a surgeon, of Camberwell-green—I attended Luscombe, I found him in bed—he had a clean-cut wound about an inch or rather larger, penetrating to the bone—it had been given with considerable force, and much against the bone, and if it had not met with an interposition of that kind it would have been very serious—he was otherwise bruised on the shoulder, such a bruise might arise from a fall, but the other was a clean cut, and must in my judgment have been caused by some such instrument as this—he has been under my care ever since, and is still unable to use his arm.

Cross-examined. Q. How are you able to know that the bone was pene
trated? A. It did not heal kindly, and an effusion of blood followed—I do not think falling on the shoulder immediately after or at the time would aggravate the appearances—if a man received a cut and fell on it the surrounding muscles might be affected—I do not think a flat stone would have done it—the macadamized roads with stones with projecting points could not do it.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you see the clothes? A. Yes, they were cat right through clean.

MR. LILLEY to J. CRUTCHER. Q. Did you see a person named Lowes after you had been before the police Magistrate? A. I never heard the name, and do not know any such person—I never spoke to a person on 25th April and said, "Good morning, Sir, you had your journey for nothing the other morning"—I do not know what you are alluding to.

MR. LILLEY called WILLIAM LOW. I am a blacksmith, and live at Pomeroy-street, Hatcham—I work in the same factory as the prisoner—he has worked there sinoe June last—he has borne the character of a quiet, inoffensive man—he lives in the same street, and I never saw him drink so much as half a pint of beer—I never knew him quarrel with a man—on 12th April, about twelve at night, I was going to the Victoria Arms, and saw him standing outside the door—he was very tipsy, I have not the slightest doubt about that—I said, "Charley, why do not you go home?"—he said, "Well, I am going," and made a bit of a move—the tallest policeman came across the road to him and said, "Are you going home?"—Charley said, "You mind your own business, you go and do your duty"—and he laid hold of him by the jacket and said, "It is my business to clear the street of such vagabonds as you"—he left go of him and he regained his feet across the road—the policeman took him by the neck and jerked him in that position from the Victoria down to Powis-court, where the prisoner got away from him—a man named Croucher, a cow-keeper, was there, but he was very tipsy, he could scarcely stand—I went to the Victoria for some beer for supper—I had not had as much as half a pint—I had been working overtime—when the prisoner got away from the policeman, the policeman drew his staff from one of his pockets, and Cox, the shorter policeman, hit him on the jaw and knocked him down—he ran to the other side, and the tall policeman hit him with his

staff across the middle of the arm, and then he ran across the road again and through Powis-court—I said to Cox, "Why do not you leave this man alone? he is a very quiet man, if you leave him for a few minutes he will go home"—he said, "Yes, I will, but my mate won't"—I saw no knife, if there had been one in the prisoner's hand at that time I must have seen it; I was close to him—I never saw him use a knife like this (produced), and I have known him some months—I never knew him to have anything more than a small pen-knife, which he used to take pieces of dirt out of men's eyes with, and he used to borrow my knife sometimes—I used a rasp, and pieces of scale very often fly from the iron into the eyes—when I arrived at the Victoria Arms it was shut—(I saw Crutcher the same week that the hearing was at the Court)—the policeman was picked up by Crutcher, and he picked his hat up for him and wanted to know which way he had gone, which he actually did not know—I took the policemen down the street and walked with them—I saw no sparring between Luscombe and the prisoner with his staff—I saw him strike at him in the middle of the road—I could not hear any policeman say, "Look out for the knife, or mind the knife,"because I was behind the two policemen when Cox received the blow—I heard Luscombe make no complaint while I was there.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. You worked with the prisoner? A. No, I worked for the same firm—I was not out with him during the Easter holidays—I was at work—I went to the Victoria that night about five minutes past 12, for the first time—I had come from Greenwich, from my wife's mother's—I wfent to fetch my wife home—I went to the Victoria for my supper beer—I had a brother there, and I ran to get some beer—he is at home—I generally go to the Victoria for my supper beer, and they were just coming out—the house was closed, but I knocked at the door—the landlord opened it and I got the beer—the policeman was standing on the other side of the road—Luscombe came right across to the prisoner, and a number of men who had just come out of the Victoria—the milkman was standing on the other side of the way—I did not see the prisoner remain there after his mates had left—he was there—he remained by himself—there was nobody but I and the fmillrmjui—Luscombe came over and said, "Are not you going homef"—he said, "Go and mind your own business; go and do your duty," and Luscombe collared him by the neck, shoved him across the road, and said, "It is my duty to clear the streets of such vagabonds as you"—nothing was said about his having been previously at the station that night—he pushed him up the street, and Cox followed, and the milk
man and I, until they came to Powis-court—I know where the prisoner lives—they went opposite his house, and pushed him past it—the prisoner got away when Luscombe was shaking him, and he put his hand behind to get his trunchepn—Cox ran in between, and the prisoner hit him with his left hand on the jaw—Cox lay on the ground about two minutes—Crutcher picked him up, and then he ran into Powis-court—that was immediately after Cox was knocked down—I swear there was no knife—it was just under a gas lamp, and if there had been a knife I must have seen it—I never heard a word about a knife—I do not know whether the policeman stabbed him
self, but I never saw anybody by whom such a cut could have been inflicted on him—I never heard of it till next morning, and I am quite sure he was not stabbed that night; if he was it was when he was in the other street—I did not see him stagger while he was in my presence—I did not follow them to Powis-court or to the station—I went a week afterwards to the police-court—I did not know that the charge was not true, because he might

have done it in the other street—no one gave evidence in his favour that I know of—I have not visited the prisoner—I know him by working with him hut if a man comes in drunk we know that he is a drunken man—he works up to nearly 8 o'clock, and sometimes till 10—I am a blacksmith and boiler-maker—he does not work in the same shop—I never saw him drunk—if I go for a walk I might meet him by chance, just as I might meet you—I have no other means than that of knowing whether he is a sober man—I never saw him quarrel in my life—I never heard anything of his knocking down the woman on the previous night—I heard it at the police-court—I heard her say that he struck her, but never heard her say that she was covered with blood.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Did you ever see him drunk before that night? A. Never; I have had opportunities of seeing him before, of an evening—there were twenty or thirty men on the drink on this Easter holiday—they were not at work that week—I was at the police-court, but was not called—I went to know whether there was any truth in the case—I understood that the stabbing had been in the other street.

SAMUEL BARRACLOUGH . I am a boiler-maker, of Pomeroy-street, Hatcham—I work at the factory—I was with the prisoner on 11th April, in the evening, at a public-house in the Bath-road, and saw there the witness who has been examined here to-day, and another woman, Coombs—they were in the side bar of the public-house—the prisoner and I were drinking in the front bar—they beckoned to us to go to them—we did so, and they asked us for a drop of gin—the prisoner paid for half a pint of gin and peppermint, and a couple of biscuits—the prosecutrix and the female had some words, and went out—the prisoner followed her, and caught hold of her arm—she wrenched hold of his hand, said he had hurt her, and struck him—he took no notice, but took it in good part, and struck her again—she struck him on the face, in the jaw—she came inside, and he came after her—she struck at him again—he said, "Drop that"—she struck him again, and he said, "If you don't be quiet, I shall smack your face"—she struck him again, and he smacked her face—she was not covered with blood—shehad a slight scratch on her cheek, but I perceived no blood—we came out to go home, to get ready for work in the morning—they were outside, and said that they would give the prisoner in charge to the first policeman they came to—we went down Pomeroy-street, and met a policeman—she said, "I give that man in charge to you"—he said "What for?" she said, "For smacking my face" he took his lamp, looked at her face, and there was a scratch on it—the prisoner said, "She struck me several times, didn't she, Sam?" I said, "Yes"—he had his light there, and Baid, "Where did he strike you?" she said, "Here"—he could see no mark, but collared the prisoner by his handkerchief, and said, "You come with me," holding him with one hand, and the light with the other—the prisoner said, "Let me go; if you want me to go with you, I will go quietly"—the policeman let him go, and we all went away together to the station—I wanted to go in, but they would not allow me, and policeman 161 and the other went in together—I did not hear the prisoner utter any threat at that time, or strike Luscombe any blow—I was near enough to have seen him do so—I continued near them until they reached the station at Peckham—I am positively sure no blow was struck by the prisoner—I have known him since February—he has been quite mild since I have known him—he has not been accustomed to fight with people.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you not call knocking down a woman anything?

A. He did not knock her down, he simply slapped her face with his open hand—the mark on her face was not a bump, it was a scratch; his finger
nail must have cut her face—I perceived no blood on her shawl; I can only speak to what I saw—he did not knock her down' m the public-house; he hit her with his open hand—he did not hit her with his fist on the jaw, and knock her down—I will swear she was not knocked down by him in my presence, and I was there all the time—I did not see her fall down—the other woman was sitting in a chair when this business was going on—the prisoner and I did not force her into the public-house, force her down into a chair, and keep her there—they did not try to leave the public-house—I did not hear him, when the policeman took him, Bay anything about two aach b—stinking w—s, nor "If you lay hands on me I will lay you dead in the road;" nothing of the kind—I followed them all the way to the station—he did not say, going to the station, "I will do for you; I will watch you"—I work with the prisoner—I have never drank with hint before that night, unless it might be a night when we were having a pint of ale after supper, and then gone home—I have never been in his company above twice before in a public-house—the landlord was not present at the Bath tavern when this little bit of a woman was beating this man—the mistress was there—I do not know whether she is here—I never saw the barman.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Did you see this man knock down Coombs or the other woman? A. No, and I was there all the time, so that I most have seen it—when the charge was made by the woman to the policeman, the prisoner mid, "She struck me several times over on the face"—the prisoner came away with me from the station.

SARAH CURTAIN . I am the wife of John Curtain, of Pomcroy-street, Hatcham—on the night of 12th April I was standing at my doof at half-past 11 o'clock, waiting for my husband—a policeman spoke to me as he passed; I have not seen him here to-day that I know of—I saw another policeman; a short one—they crossed over to the Victoria tavern, which is right opposite, and the short policeman stayed a little time, till the tail policeman came and went into the Victoria, and brought out a pint pot—those are the two policemen, (Luscombe and Cox)—they partook of it; the tall one then took it back—Orutcher, the milkman, came up, and a joke passed between them—Crutcher was very tipsy—Mr. Greedy was turning them all out of his house, as it was 12 o'clock, and the prisoner came out and crossed to the kerb—I knew him before going backwards and forwards—they were on the edge of the pavement, against the sign-poet, drinking the beer, and Crutcher in front of them—I did not observe how the prisoner came out; it was very dark; they had douted the lamps—I went in half an hour before to ask for my husband, and the prisoner was very tipsy in front of the bar, bat I did not notice what state he came out in, whether steadily or not—my husband came oat after the prisoner, and persuaded him to go quietly up the street—I remained at my door the whole time till Vowles went away—my husband pursued him, but he said he would not go home, because he knew his mates were not gone home—when the policeman went away my husband took him up the street, and laid hold of his arm—Vowles needed support; he was very tipsy—when he was gone the policeman knocked at the public-house door—Mr. Greedy said, "Who is there?" and while they were talking, the prisoner came down again, and knocked at the door—the policeman said, "You go away home," in a very gruff manner—the prisoner said, "You go away, and go on your duty"—the

policeman said, "You had better be off home," and be pusbed him in jerks, and collared him by the back of the coat—he got him past where he lodged, and we did not go any further—I crossed the road, and saw him go away—he is a very rough, powerful man, but a very sober man—it is very seldom he gets drunk—the policeman said, u Do not be mistaken; we took him last night; he is the biggest coward out; I gave him two or three good shakings last night; he is the d—dest coward out"—he went up the street with my husband, and we heard a running away—the prisoner was very tipsy; he could scarcely stand—I did not see the policeman take his staff out; neither of them had their staves out in my presence.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear the prisoner say anything to the policeman? A. I did not—the policeman said something about going to the station last night, but the prisoner did not—the prisoner went across the road to the other side—the policemen were not there then—my husband was trying to get him home—he did not cross the road directly after he got out of the public-house—his mates live on the other side, and he said he would go and see if they had come home—I have seen one of his mates here, Barraclough.

COURT. Q. You saw him on this night? A. Yes—he was very drunk, and he went home before Vowles came out—the prisoner went and knocked at his door—the policeman was then on the Victoria side of the road—my husband went with the prisoner—I saw the prisoner talking to the policeman, but do not know what was said—there were no loud words at all, or noise, or hallooing, or disturbance—I am quite sure I saw no staff taken out—I saw the policeman with his staff out afterwards—we were still at the door when we heard the running, we had never gone in.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Is your husband here? A. No; nor is the landlord or landlady of the public-house that I am aware of—the policeman fell in Powis-place—he jumped up and ran again directly; and the prisoner stopped and the policeman stopped—the policeman stood on the pavement and the prisoner in the road—I said, "Oh! policeman, do let the poor man go home"—he went like this, and I said, "Oh, policeman, hit a woman!"—he said, "I will hit anybody that interrupts me"

COURT. Q. Where was Mr. Low? A. I do not know—he persuaded the prisoner to go home—I heard the prisoner's voice after the prosecutor said that—he cried for mercy, and he called for my husband; I knew his voice—Mr. Low was not there at the time my husband persuaded the prisoner to go away; he came after that, when the prisoner came back, but I did not know him—he was there when the prisoner said, "You go away home, and do your duty"—he went with the prisoner past my house, and I did not see what became of him after that—I did not see the prisoner fall—I saw Luscombe fall—I did not see Cox, the short policeman, at that time—I went up to where the policeman fell—I did not see Cox lying on the ground—my husband is at work; he has not beeu here—he did not know that he would be required—I did not go before the Magistrate—my husband was not very tipsy, but he had had enough beer.

ANN FOX . I am the wife of James Fox, of Pomeroy-street—on Friday night, 12th April, a few minutes before 12 o'clock, I sent my daughter Ellen into the Victoria, while I waited outside—I saw the two prisoners standing by the sign-post and one of them had a pot in his hand—I did not see the prisoner or hear his voice; all I heard was talking inside the Victoria.
ELLEN FOX . I am a daughter of the last witness—I went into the Victoria on 12th April, at a few minutes to 12 o'clock, while she waited outside—I
saw the prisoner then very much the worse for liquor—there were two persons standing outside, one had a pewter pot in his hand—they were still there when I came out, I saw no one with them.

ELIZABETH GRAY . I live in Pomeroy-street, Hatcham—the prisoner has lodged with me since a week before last Christmas—I knew nothing of him before further than seeing him pass to go to work—his character has been very good—he has been a sober industrious young man—I never saw this knife in his possession.

MR. METCALFE called ELIZABETH COMIS. On 11th April I had been in the Bath tavern with a young woman, a friend of mine, having gin and peppermint—the prisoner was at the private bar, but I did not see him at first—he had this young man with him (Barracfough)—as I was coming out the prisoner was at the door with a glass of ale in his hand, and asked us to drink it; we refused—his friend caught hold of my friend and the prisoner caught hold of me by the arm, and pushed me back in at the private entrance, and asked us both what we would have to drink; we said that we had had quite enough—my friend said, "If we have anything we will have some gin and peppermint"—we had some and called for two biscuits—and then the young men went behind the door with my friend, talking to her—I was standing by myself, and wont out to see the time, I found it was twenty-five minutes to 10—I said, "Come, Sarah, it is time we got home, your mother will wonder where we are"—she came running out and the prisoner got hold of her in a shocking manner—I said, "You, leave her alone, and let her come on"—he instantly caught hold of me behind and got my head partly doubled to my feet—I said, "You good for nothing creature, you had better let me alone"—he said, "Come tick and have some drink"—I tried to get away, but could not, and he struck me on" the jaw and dug his nail into my hand; here is the mark now—he went away in at the private entrance, and I went in and stamped my foot and said that he should not strike me like that—I struck at him and he struck me two blows, one was over the eye, and I instantly fell senseless—the people ran round and got me in the parlour, ordered the company to go out, and begged me not to let the prisoner go away—the policeman brought Borne water, and my friend washed my face—I sent my friend out to see if there was a policeman—she never returned, and I found the two men walking away—I called, "Police," but no assistance came—I afterwards gave the prisoner in charge—the blows were struck violently with his full force; here is blocd on my shawl now, but it has dried in.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Is Sarah here? A. No; I did not beckon to the men, or speak to them at all—nor did Sarah in iny presence—we drank with them—I do not get my living in any other way besides that which I have mentioned—I was coming home from my work in the Bath-road—I struck at the prisoner once, I cannot say whether I struck him—he did not show the policeman the mark on his face, he said, "She struck me on the face"—there was no mark to be seen—I mean to say that the blood on this shawl came from my face—my nose bled where the cut was, and over my eye-I mean to say that the blood trickled down from my nose—I have not washed it since—I had not passed half a dozen words with the prisoner, and I gave him no cause—I went with him to the station, and heard that I might take out a summons—I went to take one out, but did nob, because there was a misunderstanding; Mr. Mprton did not under
stand my woids.

JAMES LUSCOMBE (re-examined). There was a good deal of blood on the front of the last witness's shawl—it came from the cut on her nose and eye
brow, and there was a little bit of a scar on her cheek.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hold the light to her face? A. Yes; there was not the least bit of mark to be seen on the prisoner's face—the blood on the shawl was quite fresh—the charge was refused at the station—I showed the blood there, and the woman showed her nose.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY
on the Second Count. —
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

497.
ANN HOWLETT (24)
, Stealing 1 watch, value 30l., of
Mary Patrick from her person.

MARY PATRICK . I am a widow, residing at 2, Frederick-terrace, Com
mercial-road, Peckham—on the evening of 5th April last, about half-past 5, I was coming out of my house—I had to go round the corner to Camden-grove, and as I turned, about twenty or thirty yards off, I saw the prisoner and another at the opposite side; they came up to me and asked me the way to the Kent road—I had to turn round to tell them—I pointed with my hand; they said a gentleman had directed them wrong the other day and asked me to show them right, and asked if they had to cross a field—I said, "Yes"—they then asked if they should be able to get an omnibus—I should say our conversation lasted about four minutest—during that time I had sufficient opportunity of seeing them, they were very near to me—the moment I turned round I missed my watch—they were then both in sight—I just looked down and saw that my chain was hanging—I turned round and said, "I have lost my watch, that woman has got it"—when I called out, the prisoner and her companion ran away; they were near enough to hear me—when I left my house I had my watch safe—I had not spoken to any one from the time I left my house till I saw these women—after I called out and saw the women running, a man came directly to me and said, "What have you lost?" and put his hands on each of my shoulders—I think it was to stop me, but I would not let him—I got away and followed after the prisoner and her companion as fast as I could—I never saw the man afterwards—I was at the corner that leads into the Commercial-road—I followed them and called out, "Stop the women, they have robbed me of my watch"—the prisoner was stopped almost directly afterwards, at the Rosemary Branch public-house—I got up at the time she was stopped—she had a muff in her hand; she was taken into the parlour and was kept there till Sergeant Castleman came—the other woman ran up a very quiet street, there was no one to stop her.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Were there many people in the street? A. No, very few about—I can't say how many; it was not dark, it was about half-past 5—I had not met either of them before they came up to me—I don't recollect seeing any persons iu the street, these were the only persons I saw—I had looked at my watch the moment I came out of my house—the prisoner was taken before I got up, a few minutes' walk from where the robbery took place—a gentleman had hold of her when I came up—he is my next door neighbour—I don't think he is here—there was a crowd round the public-house—he came up in the crowd—I lost sight of her for a moment rouud Camden-road—when she was takeu I said, "You have got my watch,"—she said, "I am very
