respectable, I have not" I—was very confident she had got it; I have never seen it since—they had got round the corner when I called out—they were near enough to hear me; they were about twelve feet from me, and about half as far from the comer—I lost sight of them momentarily—I saw them when I turned the corner—the other woman turned down a street on the right band side—I don't know what became of her—I suppose it is about two minutes walk from the corner to the Rosemary Branch—she declared she knew nothing about it.
MR. LILLEY. Q. Have you any doubt that this was one of the persons who enquired the way to the Kent-road? A. No doubt at all.

ALFRED CASILEMAN (Police-Sergeant P, 38). In consequence of informa
tion I received on the afternoon of 5th April, I went to the Rosemary Branch—I there received charge of the prisoner—I told her the charge, and she said she was innocent—she said she lived at 34, Norland-square, Notting-hill—I went there—she said she had been to 34, Wellington-street, Peckham—there is no such street as that—I have been resident there between seven and eight years—I know every inch of the ground.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose the prisoner was searched? A. She was searched at Camberwell-station—I did not search her—she was taken in Camberwell—I have been in Peckham about eight years—there is not a Wellington-street in the whole of Peckham—I know all the new streets—there was not a great crowd, not more than half a dozen people—it is about 200 yards from where the old lady lives, to the Rosemary Branch.
GUILTY .

p.hi: The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted.

div1.p:
WALTER HOLMES (Policeman F 3). I produce a certificate—(Read: "Bow Street, August 25, 1856:
Ann Waters, Convicted of stealing a gold watch. Confined Six Months.") The prisoner is the person who was convicted under that name.

GUILTY.†—
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

498.
THOMAS CHEESEMAN (20)
, Robbery with violence on
Dennis Bryan, and stealing from bis person 9s. his monies.
MR. LILLEY conducted the Prosecution,
DENNIS BRYAN , the prosecutor, was called on his recognisance, but did not appear.

ANN JONES . I live at 17, William-street, New Kent-road—I know Dennis Bryan; he used to live at the same place; he did on Sunday, 29th April—on that day, about 2 o'clock in the afternoon, I saw him at the door of the house standing in the passage; some females came up; one of them tied a stone in her handkerchief and struck Bryan on the head—I saw the prisoner about ten minutes after—he rushed into the passage, knocked Bryan down, and kicked him violently while down he then got up and ran out, and the prisoner ran after him—I saw nothing more—Bryan left that house on the following Thursday; he had been to the police-court on Wednesday the day before—I was present when he was examined before the Magistrate—the prisoner was at that time charged.

Prisoner. Q. What time was it when Bryan was standing at his door? A. Just about 2 o'clock—I live down stairs; he told me he had been rubbed about half-an-hour after—he did not tell me he was coming round to your house with a policeman—the disturbance began by Harriet Cross coming round and challenging the other young woman—Bryan pushed her away from the door—they had not been drinking in our house—I did not see you take anything.

EMMA SHORE . I live 17, William-street, New Kent-road—on the after
noon

of Sunday, 29th April, I saw Bryan standing at the door of his house—I also saw the prisoner, he rushed into the passage, knocked Bryan down, and kicked him, and ill-used him very much—I saw him pick up two two shilling pieces, and he had more money in his hand—I did not see where the money came from, only from the floor as he picked them up—I saw that the prosecutor's trowsers were torn very much by the pocket—I had seen his trowsers before the scuffle; they were not torn at that time; no other portion of his dress was torn—Bryan then ran into the back yard, and the prisoner after him—the prisoner afterwards came up and went down the street—he walked out—Bryan was in the yard, frightened to come out.
COURT. Q. How old is Bryan? A. I don't know; he is not an old man—I saw some stones coming into the passage; there were some women throwing stones; I suppose at Bryan.

MR. LILLEY., Q. About how old is he? A. About thirty-two or thirty
three—he is rather thinnish.

MARY ANN M'CARTHY . I live at 3, Thames-street, near William-street, at the back of William-street—on Sunday afternoon, the 29th, between 2 and 3, I heard a disturbance there—I went to the door, 17, William
street, and saw the prosecutor on the ground, and the prisoner kicking him—I saw two 2s. pieces fall on the ground, and I saw the prisoner pick them up—I did not observe where they fell from—they were both struggling—I heard Emma Shore say it was Bryan's money—I saw the prisoner's left hand by the side of the prosecutor's pocket, and his trowsers were torn down—the money fell to the ground at the same time the trowsers were torn.

COURT. Q. Were you one of the women who had the stone in the pocket
handkerchief? A. No; I saw the woman in the road getting a stone.

499.
WALTER GRIMSTONE BOND (32)
, Unlawfully obtaining 3l. from
James Mitchell by false pretences.

JAMES PEEK . I reside at Blackheath—my son, Edward Peek, and another, carry on the business of bread and biscuit manufacturers at Mill-street, Dockhead—I occasionally go to the premises, though not a member of the firm—the prisoner was in the employment of the firm, and had the manage
ment of the stablea—there is no Mr. James Peek in the firm—I never authorized the prisoner to shoot, or in any way to dispose of, the horses of the establishment—there is no pretence for such an assertion—I cannot imagine why he should have said so—he never asked me anything about them, in the way of shooting or disposing of them.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLERY. Q. Although not a member of the firm, are you accustomed to go there frequently? A. Yes; nearly every day of the week when in town, on my way to town—I do not recollect going twice a day—I may have done so—I had no distinct office there of my own—there was a desk that I made use of, and of which I kept the key—it had papers in it connected with the business of the firm—I had some conver
sation with the prisoner on one occasion with respect to the horses—I think he was there about three months—I received information that the horses under his care looked rather better, and complimented him on it, by way of encouragement—he did not exactly complain, but he mentioned that two of them were not equal to their work—I think the work is rather heavy—

I do not know whether one of the horses was a grey aud the other a brown—I have been in the stables on one or two occasions when they were going to be repaired, but I think I never was there when the hones were there—I frequently write to a country traveller named Newman on behalf of the firm—sometimes I have given directions to persons in the establishment by direction of the firm, but only to the clerks; I do not remember any others—I was not in the habit of going to the factory at all—I do not think I have ever given directions without being asked—I do not remember giving any instructions except in this way, that when the clerks have been about forming a new set of books I have suggested several things, which they have carried out—so far as my being a friend and relation of the firm they had that authority—I do not know how many horses were under his care.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did you ever authorize him to dispose of those horses? A. Not at all.

JOSEPH BURGESS MEAD . I am general manager to the prosecutors—the prisoner was in their employment about three months, and had care of the stables and hones—I never authorized him to sell or shoot any of the horses—I asked him, on 30th March, if he had sold or offered for sale any horse or horses belonging to the firm—his reply was that he had done nothing of the sort; that he was aware such rumours were about, but they were entirely without foundation—every six months we take a general stock; this happened to be at the time of the general stock taking—it was the prisoner's duty to hand in, on 31st March, an account of the stock with respect to the horses—we did not receive it from him, in consequence of which I received this note from him—it was put in evidence at the police court—(Read: "Sir, I am so unwell that I cannot attend to my duties this day, but I hope to be able to do so to-morrow, and trust my absence may not cause you any inconvenience.—G. D. Bond")—information was given me which led me to go and see a milkman named Mitchell, who I found had possession of one of my master's hones—I did not see the prisoner from that time till after he was apprehended—I went to his house previously, and was unable to find him there—he was taken into custody by my direc
tions either on the Tuesday night or the Wednesday morning—the two horses, which are the subject of this inquiry, had been, up to the 1st March, in my employer's stables, and had been daily used—I cannot possibly say when I saw them last—I saw two horses at the police court; they were my employer's property—I had seen them in my employer's possession within a week of the prisoner's apprehension—I saw them some time in March—one was a grey hone, and the other was a kind of a brown or bay.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner was what you call the general super
intendent of the horses and the stables, was he not? A. Just so; he had also charge of the harness and things—I did not buy these horses—Mitchell may, at times, supply the firm with milk—he brings milk there, which is sent by railway, from the station—I was on the premises the whole of the Saturday, excepting when I was looking for some one—he was there in the course of Saturday, the 31st—my duties do not require my presence on the Sunday—he may have been there to look after his duties on the Sunday, without my knowing anything about it—on the Monday night I received the note which has been read—my time of leaving varies—on that Monday it would have been very late; I should think 11 or 12 o'clock, because we were engaged in stock affairs—on the Friday I was there till late, and the prisoner would have been there nearly the whole of the night—my impres
sion

is that it would have been late in the evening when I left; on Monday—I have no positive recollection—I was in my office when I asked him about the horses—he came in to see me about some other matters, or was passing through the office—he would have been making preparation for taking his portion of stock in the factory—all the offices have windows looking into the yard, but mine is arranged so that I can see a little of both yards, but not so much of the second yard—Mitchell would generally drive into the one that I could not see so well—Mr. Peek's window looks directly into the second yard, and mine does partially—there were twelve horses on the establishment—the two that I saw at the police-court were lame—the work required of the horses in our employ is rather heavy; continuous work, and long journeys—it has been reported to me at times that the grey and brown horses were not in proper condition—then we had others, and they were relieved for the time—that might have meant that they were too lame to do their work without rest.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Is your work very heavy, and requiring horses of peculiarly good condition to do it? A. Not very heavy—they have to go long distances—Mr. Edward Peek seldom or ever comes down there—Mr. Frean is the partner—he would be consulted in the business, but nothing would be done without my being made fully cognisant of it—if there had been any to be bought or sold it would have come under my super
intendence.
COURT. Q. How many horses did you ever buy? A. There were two bought just as I came—the prisoner was never authorized by me or by any of the firm, as far as I know, to buy or sell any horses.

JAMES MITCHELL . I am a dairyman, of 6, George Yard, Berraondsey—I work for the prosecutors—early in March the prisoner called at my plaee and asked me if I knew any one who had got a horse to let on hire—I told him I did not, and that I wanted to buy one myself, a cheap horse—he said that he had two cripples of the firm for sale, and I could take either on trial—I first had a bay horse—I drove him to Waterloo station and back with milk to the premises, and then returned him, as he did not suit me—I went round a day or two after, and he sent me a grey horse, which he asked 10l. for—I tried it, and gave him 9l. 10s. for it; 3l. 10s. first, and then 6l.—I paid the 6l. on 22d March; this (produced) is the receipt for it—on 2d April he came to me, and told me he was disappointed in a horse coming in, and asked me if I could lend him the horse to work for the firm at 7s. per day, and next morning he went to my stables for the horse—I sent to the firm for it next day, but did not get it back—the brown horse did not suit me, and the prisoner sold it in my presence to Mr. Coleman for 9l. 10s. and allowed me 1l. for my trouble and for the introduction—after I had paid for the hone, and got possession of it, the prisoner came to my stable one morning, and said, "Do not say anything about having paid for the horse until quarter day, and then I shall have replaced the other horse."

Cross-examined. Q. You say you gave 9l. 10s. for the grey horse; was that a sufficient price? A. Yes, for a crippled horse—I refused the brown horse because he was a bigger one than the grey—he was crippled too—we had the chance of his getting better or worse; and if I went into a fair or any place, I should not like to give more than 10l., in my judgment, for such a horse, I did not buy it on my own judgment, I asked other people's opinion about it: in consequence of which I paid the prisoner what I did—the prisoner offered a receipt—9l. 10s. was a sufficient price for the brown horse in the state lie then was—the prisoner told me I need not pay a

farthing for the grey horse, I could work it out, as I worked for the firm—I said that I would much rather pay for him—my man left my premises with the grey horse in my van before I concluded the purchase.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Do you mean to persist in the statement that, in your opinion, the horse you bought was only worth 9l. or 10l.? A. I should not like to give any more for it; but I am not a horse keeper—I do not believe he was worth any more for any poor man to buy—I was examined twice before the Magistrate—it was on the second occasion that I told the Magistrate the prisoner said that I need not pay for him, but could work it out for the firm.

COURT. Q. You say that you took the brown horse back to the premises yourself? A. I returned him by my young man, who is not here—he took the brown horse back, as well as the grey, about 3 o'clock to the stable—I cannot tell whether that is a busy time, but I should say not—not many of the young men are going about then, they are out with their horses.

COURT. to J. K. MEAD. Q. Is 3 o'clock a time when you ars all about? A. We are all there at that time—it is quite possible that I may have seen the milkman coming in from the stable, and not known the horse in harness—we have a constant succession of carts and vans coming in at all times of the day—our men might know our horses if they saw them in the shafts of Mitchell's cart, but it is not likely—the stable man would, but he would not be there at that time of day—besides Messrs. Green and Peek's horses, others come in twenty times a day.
CLARA COLEMAN . I am a widow, and a greengrocer, of 23, Bedfordbury—on 23d March I bought a brown horse of the prisoner for 9l. 10s.—he said he was a cripple and unfit for the work he was doing.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you receive any information with respect to its value before you purchased it? A. No—I know nothing about horses, I have lately lost my husband, and my business cannot be carried on without a horse—the prisoner did not tell me that the horse was Peek, Frefen & Co's. but I heard that he was employed there.
MR. LILLEY. Q. Did not he say that the horse was not fit for the factory work? A. Yes—we were close to the Dookhead factory at that time.

JOHN TIMOTHY HUGHES (Policeman, M 249). I took the prisoner on 3d April, and told him he was charged with stealing two horses belonging to his employers, Peek and Frean; he said "Mr. Peek said I might shoot the horse;" I said, "But there are two horses;" he said nothing to that—he did not say to me which Mr. Peek it was, but at the police court next day he said Mr. James Peek.

Cross-examined. Q. When he said that Mr. Peek told him to shoot the horse, was it not "to shoot or sell the horse"? A It is quite possible—I will not swear he did not—he did not ask me to send for Mr. Mead, the general manager—he did say that he was so satisfied that he could clear up everything he had done that he wished Mr. Mead to be sent for.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Were you present next day when Mr. Mead was at the police-court? A. Yes; the prisoner had an opportunity of speaking to him—I saw another person, Mr. Welsh, the night before, to whom the prisoner said that Mr. Peek gave him permission to sell.

CLEMENT LOWER . I am a veterinary surgeon—I examined a brown and a grey horse, which I afterwards saw at the police-court—they were worth about 40l. or 45l.—they were not fit to be shot—they were both lame, but in pretty good condition, performing their ordinary work—they were fit for heavy work.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you assistant to Mr. Erne? A. Yes; he ex
amined them and passed them for the firm—I knew that one of these horses was blistered and turned out some time before on account of the spraining of the tendon of the fore leg, that is lameness—they were both lame when I examined them—one was very lame—it is a lameness from which horses recover with difficulty—whether I would give 20l. or 25l. for a lame horse depends upon what I wanted it for—I personally examined the horses when they were passed.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. What was their value in your judgment at the time they were bought eighteen months ago? A. About 40l. or 45l. each—there are degrees of lameness—these horses were in a condition to work at the time—I saw them at the police-court, and they have been at work ever since—the lameness was a sprain—it is shod with leather now—that was done at the prisoner's wish, in consequence of the lameness.
MR. SLEIGH to J. B. MEAD. Q. Did the prisoner ever tell you that he had sold these horses, or pay any money on account of the sale? A. No; he denies having sold them.
GEORGE SMALL . I am a dairyman, of Hop-gardens, Charing Cross—I was present when Mrs. Coleman bought the horse of the prisoner for 9l. 10s—I paid the money and took it to Mitchell.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you pay the money at the prosecutor's stables? A. Yes; in the stable—Mitchell took the money oub of my hands—there was a stable man present, in and out, but he was not there at the moment the money was paid—we were all talking openly about the transaction.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Was any one of the stable men joining in the conversa
tion or standing with you three? A. No; nor within hearing that I know of.
NOT GUILTY .

500.
WALTER GRIMSTONE BOND was again indicted
for unlawfully obtaining 3l. of
James Mitchell, and 8l. 10s. of
Clara Coleman, by feloni
ously pretending that he had the authority of
George Hender Frean and another to sell certain horses.

JAMES MITCHELL . The evidence given by this witness in the former case was read over to him, to which he assented, and added—When the prisoner offered me the horse, I believed it was one of the horses of the firm, and that he had authority to sell it; I paid the money under that belief.
COURT. Q. Are you the prosecutor of this indictment? A. No; if I do not get the horse I shall prosecute in the County Court.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. When you had got the horse, did you mention it to Simpson? A. Yes, and to all the men—I told them where I had bought the horse—there was no concealment in the transactions between me and the prisoner.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did you ever say one word about this before, that the firm knew you had bought the horse? A. Yes—I did not tell the Magis
trate so when I was examined before him.
CLARA COLEMAN . The evidence of this witness was read over to her, to which she assented.

GEORGE MEAD . I am general manager to Messrs. Peek—Mr. Peek, junior, is under age, he seldom attends to the business—Mr. Frean's depart
meut is attending the markets, purchasing wheat and flour, and arranging with me—everything that is done by the firm comes under my knowledge and cognizance—the prisoner generally receives his orders from me, but for

some little while till the business was more thoroughly established, Mr. Peek came down and assisted us—I never gave the defendant directions, directly or indirectly, to dispose of these two horses—(The witness's former evidence was here read over to him, to which he assented)—I received this notice on Monday morning, 23d April—he was there for an hour or two on Saturday afternoon—I went to his house the first thing on Tuesday morning, but he was not at home—I went twice that day and he was not at home—he did not come to the establishment, and I ordered him to be given in custody.

Cross-examined. Q. Supposing the prisoner wanted some clover for his horses, would not he ask Mr. Peek about it and not you? A. He might, because he obtained the clover from the Messrs. Peek, at Eastchot—that could be done without any communication with me, if he had arranged that the supply should come in that way—I do not remember that he has ever asked me, with respect to clover, during the whole time he has been there.

COURT. Q. Did he ever ask you for beans, or anything else? A. He would ask for oats aud beans because Mr. Peek bought them at the market—he never applied to me for cart grease—such things as breaking of harness were continually brought before me, before Mr. Bond came into the employ.

JAMES PEEK . The evidence of this witness was read over to him, to which he assented, and added—I was not there between the 20th and 30th March; I was in Devonshire—the last time I was there in March was about the 8th or 9th; I was there almost daily before that for one or two hours—it was about two months previously that I complimented him upon the look of the horses—I do not remember any conversation between us about the horses for a month previous to my departure for the country.

Cross-examined. Q. Does your memory enable you to speak with any confidence as to the last time you were there? A. I can remember up to the day I left town, that was the 8th or 9th,(Looking at a memorandum-book)—I made the memorandum at the time, it was on 9th March that I went to Devonshire, and it was about a month previous to that that I spoke to the prisoner about the condition of the horses, but I cannot say positively—I did not leave it to him to do what was right with regard to the horses—I did not order clover, straw, and corn for them—the prisoner gave me a list on two or three occasions, and I submitted it to Mr. Frean.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did you authorize the prisoner to do anything without your knowledge? A. Never.

EDWARD PEEK (Junior), I am one of the firm of Peek, Frean, and Peek—the prisoner was in our employ—I never gave him authority to sell or shoot any of the horses, or deal with them in any shape or form—I never saw him before.

p.hi: submitted there was no case to go to the Jury, as there was no proof that Mr. George Hender Frean had not given the prisoner authority to sell the horses.

contended, that having called one of the partners and the manager of the firm to prove that the prisoner had no authority to sell, that the case ought to go to the Jury, especially as it appeared, by Mr. Mead's evidence, that the primmer denied selling them at all.

div1.p: The Court considered that in an indictment for false pretences in which the authority of two persons would be necessary, it was not sufficient to prove the authority of one, and therefore directed a verdict of

501.
JAMES BARRETT (19), and
REUBEN STREAKER (19)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 153l. 10s. 3d., with intent to defraud.

JOHN PEACOCK TURNER . I am cashier of the Unity Bank in Cannon-street—on 16th April this cheque for 153l. 10s. 3d., which I have in my hand, was pre
sented to me—the name of Talleman is at the foot of it—Mr. Talleman was a customer of ours—I cashed the cheque, believing this to be his signature, but I have since discovered it to be a forgery—it is very much like his signa
ture—I cannot swear to the person who presented the cheque—Streaker is like the man—in cashing it, I gave a 100l. note, 5 ten-pouud notes, and 3l. 10s. 3d. in money—these are some of the notes that I gave.
COURT. Q. They are the same numbers you mean as those that were paid? A. Yes; I only swear to them by that.

HARRIS TALLEMAN . I am a general warehouseman, living in Houndsditch—I keep au account at the Unity Bank—this order for a cheque book is not in my writing—I never signed this cheque, but it is very much like my signatnre—I know the prisoner Barrett; he was in my employment for about five or six weeks, about five or six months ago—he had frequent opportunities of seeing my writing—he has transacted business for me at the Unity Bank; taken cheques there, and received money.

RALPH PAYNE . I am in the employ of Mr. Goad, jeweller, in the Borough—on 16th April I saw Barrett about 8 o'clock in the evening—he looked at two rings which would come to about 3l. 15s., and asked me if I could give him change for a 10l. note—I told him I would see if he would put his name at the back—he put a name at the back of the note—I said I was afraid I should not be able to give him change for it—he said he was going as far as the Elephant and Castle, and would call again—this is the note—I read the name—it was "J. Williams, 18, City-road"—I know this note by the name—he went out of the shop, leaving the note—I kept it till he returned, and then told him that I was afraid I should not be able to change it for him—I asked him where he got it from—he said that he had a friend who came into 3,000l.—I told him I was afraid I should not be able to change it for him, and he said he would go and ask his friend if he could lend him the money—he returned, and said that he was not able to find him—I told him if he left the note I should be able to change it for him in the morning—he said that he should be going past the Bank of England himself in the morning, and could get it cashed—he left me 10s. as deposit on the rings, and weut away, taking the note with him—Mr. Lyons afterwards came and brought the note—he took it away again with him—I went and gave information to the police—I went to Mr. Lyons' shop that evening and saw Barrett there—there was a policeman there, who asked him if he had any more notes, and he denied having any more—I said that I had seen him with some more notes in a bag when he took the 10l. note out—I saw a woman in Mr. Lyons' shop with him—he had not given me a 20l. note that evening to change, nor had I given him a 10l. note that evening.

CHARLES LYONS . I and my father keep a clothing establishment in the Borough—on the evening of 16th of April, Barrett came into our shop about a quarter to 9, accompanied by a young woman—he selected a stock of clothes, value 3l. 3s. and offered me this 10l. note—he told me that he had just bought two rings of Mr. Goad, had paid him with a 20l. note and had received this note in part change, and wished me to change it—I did not like his appearance—I told him that if that was the case, I would go over to Mr. Goad, and perhaps he would givemegold for it—I went to Mr. Goad's and saw Mr. Payne—I afterwards returned to my shop, and detained Barrett in the shop while Mr. Payne went for the police—he was eventually taken
into custody, and the girl also—Mr. Payne said in his presence that he saw him with other notes; but I saw nothing.

ROBERT PACKMAN (City-Policeman). On the 17th, from some information I received, I went to Stone's-end police-station, and saw Barrett there—I told him I was sorry to see him there, and asked him if his friends were aware that he was there—he said he believed they were, but he had not seen them—I said I understood he was there about Borne notes—he said, "Yes—I am; I should like to tell you the truth about it"—I have known him some years—he knows me to be an officer—I then said, "You know I am a police officer, and whatever you say I shall have to make use of in evidence against you before the Magistrate"—he then said, "I received them notes from a person last night in front of the Mansion-house"—he told me that his grandmother had lately left him between 2000l. and 3000l. and that this was some of the money to go on with—he meaut the grandmother of the person from whom he had received them; he said, "He gave me these notes to get cashed for him"—I said, "Is that man a stranger to you?"—he said, "No; his name is Reuben William Streaker, and he lives some
where near Kenuington-park"—I had, previous to seeing the prisoner, seen the four notes which the officer had—I said, "I see on the back of some of the notes there is the name of Sole and Turner, and they are solicitors in Aldermanbury, close to where you live"—he said, "Yes, I wrote the name of Sole and Turner on one of the notes, but not on all of them"—I said, "I saw you with a man in Finsbury-circus two or three days ago, who was a stranger to me"—he said, "That is the man I had the notes of"—I had seen him with another man as I told him—I saw the two prisoners together about three days previous to Barrett's being taken in custody.

Barrett. I wrote the name of Williams on the note. Witness. I did not have hem in my hand—I only saw them in another person's hand; I should not know them—I saw the name of Sole and Turner on one of them.

HENRY TIGHE (Policeman, M 226). On 16th April, I took Barrett at the shop of Mr. Lyons, clothier, High-street, Borough—there was a female in his company—this 10l. note was passed to me in Barrett's presence by Mr. Lyons—I asked Barrett where he got it from—he said he had been paid his wages in a 20l. note, which he had chauged for two 10l. notes—he said his employers were wine merchants—I asked him where the other 10l. note was—he said that he had given one 10l. note to a friend at the Elephant and Castle—I asked him if he had the bag containing the notes—he said he had not—I asked the female, in his presence—she said she had not the bag—not being satisfied with them I took them to the station—the male prisoner gave his address Barber's hall, Monkwell-street—Whiffin, the female, gave her's 54. Wood-street, Cheapside—she was searched by the female searcher, Mrs. Fenson, from whom I received this bag with the contents—it contained a 100l. note, and two 10l. notes—those are the notes which Mr. Turner has just seen—on the 17th, I called at 54, Wood-street, the address given by the female, and there I saw Streaker leaving the house—I then recollected having to seen him the previous night standing oustide Mr. Lyons'Shop during the time I was speaking to Barrett—I did not say anything to him on this occasion—I afterwards apprehended him—I told him that I wanted him for being coucerned with a man named Barrett, and a female named Whiffin, for stealing a quantity of notes—he said, "The notes are not stolen; I have done wrong, but I was led into it by Barrett"—I took him to the station, searched him, and found on him this piece of paper, which I now produce—the sums stated on this piece of paper amount to 153l. 10s. 3d.

COURT to J. P. TURNER. Q. Have you any means of knowing what time of the day the note was presented? A. I know from my books that it was between 11 and 3 o'clock—I go out at 3 o'clock, and it was before I went out—I have the book with the list of the notes which I paid away—it is about the middle of the day's entries in the book—from that I suppose that it was about the middle of the day's business; probably about 1 or 2 o'clock—I was asked for a 100l. note and five tens.

SARAH ANN FENSON . I am female searcher at Stone's-end police-station, Borough—I searched a woman named Whiffin, and found on her a 100l. note in a bag, and two 10l. notes crumpled up—I delivered them to Tighe.
Streaker's defence. The cheque was written by Barrett, and I presented it.

BARRETT—
GUILTY .—
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

STREAKER—
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE 11TH, 1860.
